greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of numbers having in binary representation the same number of zeros and ones as n has.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Digit Count
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
example: n=23->'1_0111' has 5 bits, and the lower 4 bits can be shuffled. There are 1 zero and 3 ones, so the number of combinations is C(4,1) = 4 (the zero can be in 4 positions).
n=33->'1_00001': C(5,1) = 5 (the one can be in 5 positions).
mathematica: a[n_] := Binomial[Length[b = IntegerDigits[n, 2]]-1, Count[b, 0]]; a[0] = 1; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 100}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 25 2014 *)
program: (PARI) A090706 = n->binomial(#binary(n)-1,hammingweight(n)-(n>0)) \\ About 20% faster than the alternative "...-1)+!n". - _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 04 2014
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jan 15 2004
ext: Missing a(0)=1 added and offset adjusted by _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 19 2012
